title: In Chapter 7 if I have a payment plan with the IRS, is it included on Schedule J.
question: Also, is the IRS considered a debtor and do we have to include it to be discharged in a bankruptcy. I don't like to mess with the IRS. I rather just keep paying them and get everything else discharged. After expenses we have about $180 left over. If we try to discharge the IRS we would have $383 more. Total $563 and we would not qualify. We meet income means test other wise. It because social security income is out on test and back in on Schedule J.
answers:
Generally, IRS tax debt is not dischargeable in Bankruptcy. Since the IRS repayment and the debt is a priority debt, debtors are required to disclose it in Schedule J as other installment expenses or tax payments.

In addition, debtors should pay careful attention to Chapter 7 cases in which there is a positive DMI (disposable monthly income). In cases with positive DMIs, the Chapter & trustee may refer the case to the US trustee to convert to a Chapter 13 case, because of the debtors’ ability to pay back unsecured creditors. I would recommend speaking to an local experienced bankruptcy attorney. Good Luck.

You would have to disclose the debt on Schedule E, and the payment on Schedule J.

When you file bankrutpcy, you need to list ALL your debts and ALL your assets.

Priority tax debts will not be discharged in a Chapter 7 bankruptcy and will still need to be paid after filing. Therefore, if the debt is priority debt, then you will definitely list it as an expese on Schedule J as you will need to keep making those payments.

If you speak to a knowledgable attorney or CPA, they can help you determine how much of the tax debt is priority debt. The non-prioirity tax debt can be discharged in bankurptcy and will not need to be paid.
